Award.AwardTitle: Educating Talented Scholars in Computer Science and Software Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: To address the decline in degrees awarded to domestic students in Computer Science and Software Engineering (CSSE), this project is increasing participation and retention of academically talented, financially disadvantaged undergraduate and graduate students by providing about 57 scholarships over the course of the project. The undergraduate scholars are pursuing degrees in any of the three accredited degree programs: Computer Science, Software Engineering and Wireless Engineering. Auburn University is providing full tuition waivers to graduate scholars. The project is providing a pool of skilled graduates for the workforce that will help the nation maintain a leadership position in embedded computer systems and distributed computing. Recruitment efforts are being conducted via college and departmental recruiting events, site visits, web site, office of minority engineering program, and synergy with the STARS alliance. The project is improving retention and transforming the educational experience by one-to-one tutoring, mentoring of undergraduate scholars by graduate scholars, study-groups, and field trips. Career networking and internships opportunities are being provided via industrial partnerships. The outcomes are being disseminated via conferences, journals, web site and media outlets by Auburn University's office of communication and marketing. Research is being integrated into education by participation of undergraduate scholars in the summer REU program (optional) and graduate scholar research. Formative and summative evaluations are informing the process of recruitment, retention, and placement.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project strongly impacted retention and participation of low-income undergraduate and graduate students in Computer Science and Software Engineering as well as those belonging to underrepresented groups.  The project provided scholarships to 28 students comprising of Bachelor's, Master's and Doctoral degree aspirants.  As a result of the scholarship support provided by this project, sixteen (16) students completed their Bachelor's degrees in Computer Science, Software Engineering or Wireless Software Engineering. Three students (3) completed their Master's degrees.  Three students (3) completed their PhD degrees.  One student after completing the Bachelor's degree continued towards the master's degree and was also partially supported.  Additionally, one (1) master's student and two (2) undergraduate students, who joined the project towards the latter part of the project, are on track to graduate soon.  Two students were associated in helping to administer the project--one completed the PhD degree and another is expected to complete soon.  The project supported underrepresented students--six (6) women, seven (7) African Americans and one (1) student with a disability.  The students participated in mentoring, internships and research activities enhancing their experiences.  Auburn University provided tuition waivers to graduate scholarship recipients.  Students conducted research in a variety of areas within Computer Science: Computer Systems, Educational Pedagogy in Computer Science, Modeling and Simulation and Software Engineering.   Several refereed research papers were published as a result of the research conducted by the members of the project. The students maintained high GPAs--thirteen (13) students made into the Dean's List.  The GPA averaged over all participants over all semesters was over 3.5/4.0.  The graduating students joined reputable companies in the STEM field including those in Fortune 500 companies or were admitted to graduate degree programs in Computer Science.  The 4/5-year graduation rate for undergraduates was 100%--two who took more than four years did so because of double majors (one in Physics and other in Economics) and one as a result of not being able to attend a few semesters due to disability. The net retention rate was 89%--three master's degree students left for industry jobs.  Several enrichment programs such as tutoring, summer internships, group meetings were conducted. The enrollment in the department's undergraduate program has substantially increased over the last few years.  The project met all its intellectual merit and broader impacts by: (i) achieving retention objectives (ii) high 4/5-year graduation rate (iii) collaborative student-faculty research (iv) dissemination of research results (v) recruitment and support of low-income students and of minorities and women who are underrepresented in Computer Science (vi) mentoring undergraduate students by graduate students and faculty and (vii) providing enrichment and professional development activities.   

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/01/2019
Modified by: Sanjeev Baskiyar
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project strongly impacted retention and participation of low-income undergraduate and graduate students in Computer Science and Software Engineering as well as those belonging to underrepresented groups. The project provided scholarships to 28 students comprising of Bachelor's, Master's and Doctoral degree aspirants. As a result of the scholarship support provided by this project, sixteen (16) students completed their Bachelor's degrees in Computer Science, Software Engineering or Wireless Software Engineering. Three students (3) completed their Master's degrees. Three students (3) completed their PhD degrees. One student after completing the Bachelor's degree continued towards the master's degree and was also partially supported. Additionally, one (1) master's student and two (2) undergraduate students, who joined the project towards the latter part of the project, are on track to graduate soon. Two students were associated in helping to administer the project--one completed the PhD degree and another is expected to complete soon. The project supported underrepresented students--six (6) women, seven (7) African Americans and one (1) student with a disability. The students participated in mentoring, internships and research activities enhancing their experiences. Auburn University provided tuition waivers to graduate scholarship recipients. Students conducted research in a variety of areas within Computer Science: Computer Systems, Educational Pedagogy in Computer Science, Modeling and Simulation and Software Engineering. Several refereed research papers were published as a result of the research conducted by the members of the project. The students maintained high GPAs--thirteen (13) students made into the Dean's List. The GPA averaged over all participants over all semesters was over 3.5/4.0. The graduating students joined reputable companies in the STEM field including those in Fortune 500 companies or were admitted to graduate degree programs in Computer Science. The 4/5-year graduation rate for undergraduates was 100%--two who took more than four years did so because of double majors (one in Physics and other in Economics) and one as a result of not being able to attend a few semesters due to disability. The net retention rate was 89%--three master's degree students left for industry jobs. Several enrichment programs such as tutoring, summer internships, group meetings were conducted. The enrollment in the department's undergraduate program has substantially increased over the last few years. The project met all its intellectual merit and broader impacts by: (i) achieving retention objectives (ii) high 4/5-year graduation rate (iii) collaborative student-faculty research (iv) dissemination of research results (v) recruitment and support of low-income students and of minorities and women who are underrepresented in Computer Science (vi) mentoring undergraduate students by graduate students and faculty and (vii) providing enrichment and professional development activities.
